sub_title: vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,
summary: Prof. Dr. Folkert W. Asselbergs is a consultant cardiologist, vice-chair of Amsterdam Heart Center, Prof of Precision medicine at the Institute of Cardiovascular Science and Institute of Health Informatics, University College London, Director BRC Clinical and Research Informatics Unit, UCLH, chair data infrastructure Dutch Cardiovascular Alliance (www.dcvalliance.nl), and associate editor of the European Heart Journal for the section digital innovation. He recently founded the nudging unit that will provide a framework to conduct pragmatic trials embedded within routine care for knowledge discovery and improvement of patient care by increasing guideline adherence (www.nudgingtrials.com). His research program focuses on precision medicine using real-world data from electronic health records and registries and -omics research for drug target discovery, pharmacogenetics and stratified medicine using digital twinning. He published over 600 papers and leads several(inter-) national consortia in the field of trustworthy AI, translation data science and digital health.

projects:
[{'title': 'Horizon project DataTools4Heart', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'DataTools4Heart aims to improve the lifestyle of patients suffering from cardiovascular diseases by developing a comprehensive, federated, privacy-preserving toolbox for data reuse in cardiology. The tools include a platform that will securely access data from different hospitals and transform them into their digital counterparts (synthetic data) to be used by researchers and clinicians across the world. The access into large-scale multi-source cardiology data will be facilitated by the creation of virtual assistants.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}]}, {'title': 'Heart4Data', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The key objective of Heart4Data is to create a national and sustainable infrastructure for cardiovascular registry-based research on heart failure. This infrastructure includes a governance structure, and the ethical, legal, financial and methodological framework. A proof of concept of this infrastructure will be tested by conducting two projects within the heart failure registry. The created national consortium will become part of the DCVA community and will actively contribute to the aims of the DCVA. One of the activities is to develop a sustainable governance structure, realizing a DCVA Health Data Hub, and a funding strategy for the maintenance of the infrastructure/future research projects.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}]}, {'title': 'BigData@Heart', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Launched in March 2017, BigData@Heart is a five-year project of the Innovative Medicines Initiative (IMI), a EU public-private consortium consisting of patient networks, learned societies, SMEs, pharmaceutical companies and academia.

BigData@Heartâs ultimate goal is to develop a Big Data-driven translational research platform of unparalleled scale and phenotypic resolution in order to deliver clinically relevant disease phenotypes, scalable insights from real-world evidence and insights driving drug development and personalised medicine through advanced analytics. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}]}, {'title': 'GENIUS-CHD', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'description': 'GENIUS-CHD is an international consortium of studies of patients with coronary heart disease (either stable disease or acute coronary syndromes) who have had blood or tissue samples stored for analysis and have then been prospectively followed for subsequent events such as death or myocardial infarction.

Many of these studies have been created by investigators seeking to identify bio-markers of risk or genetic variations that lead to these groups of patients succumbing to these adverse events. wereldmap

Individually the studies are relatively small and although can yield some insights, often fail to show effects due to a lack of statistical power.  Importantly negative findings are hard to interpret.  Collectively, however, these studies are powerful enough to answer many important questions and offer opportunities to replicate or validate novel findings.

To date over 63 cohorts participate in the consortium, from 17 countries, including over 270,000 patients, making this the largest effort of its kind in studying determinants of risk for subsequent CHD events', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Riyaz Suleman', 'last_name': 'Patel', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Professor of Preventative Cardiology & Consultant Cardiologist'}]}, {'title': 'National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Health Informatics Collaborative (HIC)', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The HIC is a collaboration between five leading NHS trusts, each of which has a strong relationship with a partner university. These relationships have been strengthened and supported by the NIHR, in particular through the establishment of NIHR Biomedical Research Centres (BRCs) within each trust. It is the BRCs that provide the focal points for the HIC collaboration, bringing together clinical, scientific, and informatics expertise at each trust to improve the quality and availability of patient information.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}]}, {'title': 'iGenetrain', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The International Genetics & Translational Research in Transplantation Network (iGeneTRAiN) was formed in late 2012 to bring together a number of academic research organizations and Industry partners across Europe, America and beyond.

The iGeneTrain network aims to harness the wealth of existing and emerging genomic and other relevant datasets and knowledge gained from studies in human clinical transplant research across epidemiology and translational science from a range of clinical cohorts.

Through assimilating pharmacogenomic translational knowledge from NIH consortia such as The Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) Network, which is integrating genetic variant based information into clinical dosing, iGeneTrain ultimately aims to translate this information into clinical practice.

Such patient-specific dosing for immunosuppression and other post-transplantation medications will likely reduce many drug-induced complications.

Through genome-wide data analyses in both recipient and donor (where available) we also aim to assess if it is possible to perform more optimal matching of donor-recipient pairs to discover potential genomic markers underpinning acute and chronic graft rejection.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Asselbergs', 'name': None, 'headline': 'vice-Chair Amsterdam Heart Center, Professor Precision Medicine at University College London,'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Brendan', 'last_name': 'Keating', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Associate Professor at University of Pennsylvania'}]}]
